On incestual marriage:
 Genetic disorders are often cited, and the State can argue it has a legitimate interest in preventing them. Although on this reasoning we *could* outlaw those with genetic disorders from procreating, this is not really an existing issue: those with severe genetic disorders generally do not procreate anyways, therefore there is not really a problem to legislate against. That is the reason why there isn't a law, not because of inconsistency in legal theory. Generally, we only pass laws to deal with problems that exist, otherwise there simply isn't motivation to act on it and is also a waste of effort.
 
 Sidenote: the degree to which incestual marriage is forbidden varies from state to state in the US. Many states outlaw first-cousins, other states permit it. As I understand it, the degree to which genetic disorders appear in marriages between first cousins is negligible. Even Einstein married a first-cousin.
 
 On paedophilia:
 It still baffles me why opponents of gay marriage continually bring this up. Persons under 18 years of age cannot and will never be able to legally give consent to a marriage. It is a fundamental tenet of law that there is a legal age where persons are presumed to be able to make informed consent. In the US, that age is 18. Anyone under 18 has very limited powers to provide consent. Although people under 18 can be married, they must have parent/guardian consent.
 
 On polygamy:
 I assume we're discussing simultaneous polygamy, because western countries already practice serial polygamy (aka divorce and remarriage). On the surface, I see nothing wrong with this practice, but admittedly haven't given it much thought. The sexist connotations are fairly relevant to the discussion; polygamy in the past was only permissable for men, but not women. There is also a tax implication which must be considered. Gifting is between spouses is not a taxable event, but gifting between strangers can be depending on the value of the gift. This raises the issue of abuse of polygamous marriages to avoid taxes. If you can come up with a proposal that avoids such abuse, I'd see nothing wrong with allowing it.
